As EU migrants quit the UK over Brexit, some MPs say regions like the North East should be allowed to bring in immigrant workers Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Regions such as the North East should be allowed to set their own immigration policy and give firms the right to recruit foreign workers without advertising jobs in the UK, according to a group of MPs. 
Foreign workers could be offered a North East visa allowing them to come to the UK on condition they stayed in the region for at least two years, under proposals from the All Party Parliamentary Group on Social Integration, chaired by high-profile Labour MP Chuka Umunna. 
It comes after the latest official figures showed a significant fall in net immigration, apparently caused by the EU referendum and Brexit. 
But more than half a million long-term overseas migrants are coming into the UK every year, 
The net number of immigrants moving to the North East was 9,622 over 12 month. This includes 15,572 people coming into the region and 5,950 leaving. 
There are 152,000 people living in the North East who were not born in the UK. That’s around one in 17 of the region’s entire population of 2.6 million people. Net migration has dropped to its lowest level in three years (Image: PA) 
The report by MPs says that mayors and local councils should be allowed to set immigration policies in their regions. At a minimum, they should be able to allow employers “to offer particular jobs to 
non-EU nationals without first advertising them domestically.” 
The Government should also consider allowing local authorities to offer region-specific visas, the MPs said. They added: “Immigrants would be expected to stay in a particular region for a minimum period of time (perhaps two-to-three years) before gaining the right to live anywhere in Britain.” 
The group also said every immigrant who did not speak fluent English should be required to take English classes, which they would pay for themselves under a system similar to student loans. 
MPs said their research had found many migrants felt the UK had become less tolerant since the Brexit vote. poll loading Should the North East have its own immigration policy? 0+ VOTES SO FAR Yes No 
Mr Umunna said: “The demonisation of immigrants, exacerbated by the poisonous tone of the debate during the EU referendum campaign and after, shames us all and is a huge obstacle to creating a socially integrated nation.” 
Net immigration into the UK fell significantly to 246,000 a year - because EU citizens are quitting the UK Britain ahead of Brexit. 
Despite the fall, the figures from the Office for National Statistics (ONS) show that the Government is a long way from achieving its longstanding goal of getting immigration down below 100,000. 
The total number of overseas immigrants coming into the UK was 588,000 in the 12 months up to March 31 2017. The number of people leaving the UK was 342,000. Read More Is Labour MP Laura Pidcock right to say she would never be friends with a Conservative? 
Net migration, the difference between the number coming in and the number leaving, was 81,000 lower than a year previously. 
Nicola White, ONS Head of International Migration Statistics, said the change seemed to be a result of migrants from Eastern European countries, known as the EU8, leaving the UK. 
The EU8 includes countries which joined the EU in 2004, such as Poland, Lithuania, Czech Republic, Hungary, Slovakia, Slovenia, Estonia and Latvia. Read More Lowest net migration in three years as Government plans study into international students' impact 
She said: “These results are similar to 2016 estimates and indicate that the EU referendum result may be influencing people’s decision to migrate into and out of the UK, particularly EU and EU8 citizens.” 
Tory think tank Bright Blue urged Prime Minister Theresa May to abandon the migration target, which the Government has never come close to meeting. 
Think tank director Ryan Shorthouse said: “The net migration target, which is arbitrary and indiscriminate, has consistently been missed since its introduction.” Like us on Facebook
